column5: Some people don‚Äôt get low cortisol symptoms as strongly, or feel them as well, as others. Just because you feel okay doesn‚Äôt mean you are okay. I had plenty of days I felt pretty okay before I nearly died a couple of times. That doesn‚Äôt mean I was okay. It‚Äôs dangerous and stupid.
Vomiting excessively and major surgeries wouldn‚Äôt be stress dose, that would be injection time. You don‚Äôt stress dose for low cortisol symptoms? Interesting.

To add to this, I believe they overdosed me on fludro the night I had a very strange trippy/dreamlike experience. I had a nurse almost give me a double dose after this particular night so that‚Äôs why I think that‚Äôs what happened to me.

If you have Addison‚Äôs you are supposed to be fludrocortisone. Did you mean fludrocortisone instead of fluoxetine? If you are not on it, you need to be. No amount of salt ingestion will keep your BP and sodium normalized if you don‚Äôt have the hormones necessary to hold onto the sodium in the first place. Having a low BP means your Addison‚Äôs is not being managed appropriately and this is very dangerous. I was eating and drinking salt and still ended up with life-threatening hyponatremia that nearly killed me twice.

Wow, you‚Äôre the only other person I‚Äôve met that also had an unnecessary gallbladder removal. I had mine out after 6 months of weight loss, hypotension, vomiting and abdominal pain. I still can‚Äôt believe that surgery didn‚Äôt kill me. I had to be brought into surgery in a wheel chair because I could barely walk. Was exactly a month after my surgery that I ended up in ICU and was finally diagnosed.

I‚Äôm confused by your statement. You‚Äôve never had a migraine or nausea since being diagnosed with Addison‚Äôs? Stress dosing, even as little as 5mg, is needed for those things. I don‚Äôt think not taking a stress dose implies health, I think it implies a different understanding of steroid usage and when stress dosing is needed.

If your fludro dose is too low, it won‚Äôt matter how much salt you intake because you won‚Äôt be holding on to it. 

I wouldn‚Äôt updose for muscle twitching unless you have other low cortisol symptoms going on. Muscle twitching is more of an electrolyte issue, if anything. When I had bad muscle twitching my endo had me get a metabolic panel done to check my levels out. I would ask for that to be done.
Addison‚Äôs does not cause either of those things.

It‚Äôs auto-immune, and I don‚Äôt think stress directly causes Addison‚Äôs. If high stress caused Addison‚Äôs disease it probably wouldn‚Äôt be so rare. :)

I was 100% healthy besides having severe anxiety/panic attacks since childhood. The only strange thing I remember experiencing was that every time I got sick with something that caused fever or a lot of inflammation (viruses/wisdom teeth extracted) I‚Äôd get this weird rash on both sides of the base of my neck. I asked a doctor about it once and they said it was probably my immune system overreacting. I have a family history of Hashimoto‚Äôs, diabetes, pernicious anemia, ITP, etc. About 9 months before my Addison‚Äôs symptoms hit me, I got a positive ANA test. By the time I was diagnosed with Addison‚Äôs my thyroid was also non-functional. That‚Äôs how I know it is auto-immune and bad family genetics.
You need to get a different endocrinologist. Not only are they callous but they have a fundamental ignorance of what Addison‚Äôs is apparently.
Good plan. I‚Äôm 10 months out of my hospital stay that got me diagnosed and have had no big problems since, even though I was close to dying then. I hope they‚Äôre feeling well soon.

I was sick for about 8/9 months before I was finally diagnosed in a crisis but I didn‚Äôt have most of those symptoms you listed besides dizziness but my dizziness was mostly pre-syncope symptoms like my vision going black for over a minute after standing due to extremely low blood pressure. I did have appetite but I could not eat due to the crushing abdominal pain and I lost ~35lbs over a few months due to the constant vomiting and pain. 

I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre feeling this way. I hope you get an answer. 

Did you have an ACTH stimulation test or just an 8am cortisol blood draw?

High blood pressure can be a sign of crisis just like low blood pressure. Sometimes it goes very high before plummeting. Please make sure you have a BP monitor at home. Anyone with Addison‚Äôs needs to have one available since it‚Äôs one of the only tangible ways we have of checking ourselves out. 

Chest pain can be mistaken for heartburn often. I would get a check up with a cardiologist ASAP to make sure nothing weird is going on. 

Orthostatix hypotension sounds like something is off, an underlying condition could be exacerbating your Addison‚Äôs, or your Addison‚Äôs itself isn‚Äôt being controlled properly. 

What is your dosing schedule like?

Fludrocortisone does have ‚Äúsevere mental disturbances‚Äù and ‚Äúunusual thoughts or behavior‚Äù listed under side effects. I don‚Äôt know what the mechanism for them would be. I will say when I was in ICU and had just started them I had a very strange night where I felt like I was tripping on drugs. It never happened again though. Make sure you alert their doctor about whatever happened.
I‚Äôd get new doctors then.
If you have to use an emergency injection you need to be checked out at a hospital either way.
Oklahoma
Your insurance may not pay for it but you should be able to pay out of pocket for extra refills. That‚Äôs what I did.
Hey, I was also diagnosed in August of 2019 and am 28. Feel free to message me if you need to chat. I know how you‚Äôre feeling.

Yeah, you do need help. Commenting on someone‚Äôs thread about their actual, not self-induced disease because you‚Äôre butthurt about a salad comment? Calling me a ‚Äúcunt‚Äù because of that? You need more help than AA can give you. I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre such a miserable person.
That‚Äôs not a wedge salad, genius. That‚Äôs vegetables slopped in a bowl. Apparently you‚Äôve never seen an actual wedge salad.
I think salads are supposed to feature vegetables cut into mouth-sized shapes.
Thanks for the info! I will be sure to ask for that. How much do you upside for minor dental work? And do you updose before the appointment or after?
Should we be asking for epi-free novocaine? I am planning on having my first dentist appointment since diagnosis soon. Been putting it off due to anxiety and want to make sure I have all my info.

You should feel very glad and lucky to have doctors who recognize the seriousness of a crisis and know that blood pressure is really the best indicator of being ‚Äúout of the woods‚Äù, so to speak. 

My blood pressure was at 63/30 during my 2nd crisis, which got me diagnosed, and it kept dropping steadily. I was given IV hydrocortisone but it wasn‚Äôt really enough to raise it and they put me on epinephrine and I ended up in ICU for a week. Epinephrine can be used in crisis along with hydrocortisone, I‚Äôve since learned. When my BP stayed in the 80/60 range for a day, they moved me to the progressive care unit. I was able to go home on the 7th day when my BP finally stayed at around 95/65. My normal BP before Addison‚Äôs was always 95-100/60-65 so this was fine for me but might be low for others. 

Stomach pain is also just a common symptom of an crisis. Make sure you have at least two emergency injections on you *at all times*, if you do not. Vomiting more than once is time to inject and then head to a hospital. 

Your hospital is doing what they‚Äôre supposed to be doing. Being there sucks but it‚Äôs better than being sent home when you are not out of danger. Be thankful.

I do have a blood pressure monitor at home. I didn‚Äôt think about checking it during the headaches. I‚Äôll check it when my next headache comes on. 

I think my salt intake is sufficient but I‚Äôm not sure how to measure it. I salt all my food very well and occasionally add some salt to my water when I have headaches. I guess I‚Äôm not sure where the line is for us as to getting enough salt and overdoing it.

I‚Äôm not sure how to know if it‚Äôs dehydration. I‚Äôve had random muscle twitches come and go since being out of the hospital but other than that I‚Äôm not sure how to tell. When I told my endo about my muscle twitches he sent me to get blood work and all of my electrolytes looked good. I‚Äôve had it done a few times since diagnosis now and they‚Äôve still been right in the middle of normal. Would a headache mean more sodium or more water?

How do you know if you are overdosed? I don‚Äôt have any symptoms of being overdosed as far as hydrocortisone goes. I‚Äôm already on a low dose of fludro according to the Addisonian‚Äôs I‚Äôve spoken to. I‚Äôve had multiple metabolic panels done in the last 7 months and they‚Äôve all come out well so I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs fludro related but I‚Äôm willing to try anything. 

I‚Äôm hypothyroid too and my recent tests have all come out well for that.

I didn‚Äôt imply anything was black and white. Actually, I said quite the opposite. I said just having *an* autoimmune disorder didn‚Äôt automatically mean you were immune compromised. There is a wide spectrum of autoimmune disorders. I‚Äôm aware of how stress hormones affect the body. I have Addison‚Äôs disease and I don‚Äôt make stress hormones. My point was literally that it depends on what your exact health condition and circumstances are. Obviously anyone not healthy should be careful. Didn‚Äôt say that either.

Of course they‚Äôre markers for overall health. However, there are more studies proving that it‚Äôs not a healthy choice. I‚Äôm literally showing you studies that show otherwise. Your statement that ‚Äúall scientific data show that your premise is wrong‚Äù is fundamentally flawed. You can‚Äôt cherry-pick studies you like about glucose and diabetes and then say every other study I‚Äôve linked is simply ‚Äúwrong‚Äù. That‚Äôs bizarre.

I don‚Äôt read blogs? If you actually read the articles they are siting scientific studies and you can click them. Your sources are all regarding hyperglycemia and insulin resistance. Not whether it‚Äôs healthy to drink fruit juice.

You don‚Äôt need a study to tell you that you ingest more calories drinking fruit juice than eating actual fruit. That‚Äôs called logic. 

https://www.bmj.com/content/366/bmj.l2408


https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.medicalnewstoday.com/amp/articles/325716

I can actually site sources for my claim. You cannot. Having vitamins doesn‚Äôt make something ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù. That‚Äôs just ignorant. By your assertion that would make anything with added vitamins and minerals ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù. That‚Äôs why Vitamin Water is not ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù, nor are fruit snacks with added vitamins and minerals ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù. Fruit juice is known to be unhealthy because it removes the fiber from the fruit and creates a situation where you‚Äôre ingesting the sugar content and calorie content of several times the amount of real fruit an individual would eat in reality. 


https://www.mdlinx.com/internal-medicine/article/3728

https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/fruit-juice-vs-soda

https://www.google.com/amp/s/bigthink.com/surprising-science/fruit-juice-health.amp.html
If she has shortness of breath she needs to go to the ER and hopefully she can be tested there.
If her symptoms become severe, she can go to a hospital. If they aren‚Äôt severe it‚Äôs unlikely she‚Äôs going to get tested right now. She just needs to stay isolated and treat symptoms.
Put your tinfoil hat away. You‚Äôre gullible.
Please site sources educating me on how healthy drinking sugar is? Simply stating ‚Äúwrong‚Äù makes you look stupid. Juice being unhealthy is common knowledge in 2020.
Fruit juice is awful for you no matter what brand.
Oklahoma

Steroids suppress the immune system. That‚Äôs how they work. That‚Äôs where I gathered the assumption Addison‚Äôs patients were assumed to be immunosuppressed. However, I haven‚Äôt seen that to be the case on a physiological replacement dose. 

I am curious as to what about Addison‚Äôs causes one to have a weakened immune system? I haven‚Äôt been told my immune system is affected and haven‚Äôt seen any literature that suggests this. I‚Äôm still learning so I‚Äôd like any information.

Well, there are studies showing that immunosuppression is based on steroid dosage, not simply being on steroids for physiological replacement. We are at risk due to Addison's but I have never seen a study stating our dosing makes our immune systems suppressed. Do you have any studies?
Well, if they‚Äôre mild they won‚Äôt have likely been tested.

Yes? And what‚Äôs your point? That‚Äôs the case for all viral illness. People everywhere should be keeping socializing and going out to a bare minimum to keep transmission slowed down. That‚Äôs what the advice has been.
Someone who was very sick would also be ‚Äúanecdotal experience‚Äù.
Cancelled events, avoiding unnecessary socializing and staying inside as much as possible is hardly world-changing. The tone around this sub is most definitely alarmist.

There‚Äôs going to be an explosion of cases and then it will slow down. As it has in China. This isn‚Äôt doomsday and telling people it is won‚Äôt help anyone. Staying prepared and being cautious is literally all anyone can do.
Because they haven‚Äôt been testing enough.
It is more deadly than the flu but the alarmist shit about how the we‚Äôll be living in a ‚Äúdifferent world‚Äù is not helping anyone take it seriously.

But the same fiber is present in vegetables, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm getting at. There isn‚Äôt a huge benefit to eating fruit when you get higher vitamin/mineral amounts and less calories/sugar in vegetables. Juice is definitely awful for you, agreed.
Everyone is fucked. This thing isn‚Äôt going away for a long, long time.

I get the point here but the amount of deaths so far isn‚Äôt really shocking so far when compared with the flu. It is worse than the flu, but not by an astronomical amount. The flu killed at least 12,000 people within 5 months in 2019. They estimate it may be as high as 30,000. We won‚Äôt really know an exact death rate for covid-19 till this thing goes on for long enough.
That‚Äôs not how you use hashtags.

Except your diet is only part of the equation. There is a good reason why it‚Äôs so extremely common, estimating at 1 billion people, regardless of location. 

https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/vitamin-d-deficiency-symptoms

I eat a healthy diet, live in a sunny location, and have had a vitamin D deficiency. As have many people close to me. It‚Äôs a very common issue that has layers of causation.

It‚Äôs important to realize that fruit is not the only or even best way to get those vitamins and minerals. Vegetables are a better source for vitamin C/potassium/etc. They have higher amounts than fruits have and none of the sugars. Eat your vegetables.
Unfortunately, vitamin deficiencies are common, especially vitamin D. Good diet or not.
This is the reason it‚Äôs spread so badly.
Sounds like anxiety symptoms. I‚Äôd lay off coronavirus news.

You are not automatically immune-compromised because you have an autoimmune disorder. There are many common autoimmune diseases that have no bearing on your ability to fight infection, which was my point in stating Hashimoto‚Äôs does not affect your ability to fight infection. If you believe this to be otherwise, site a scientific source.
Thank you! Sorry you‚Äôre sick. I hope you recover quickly and stay safe as well!

Mine is autoimmune too. I have Addison‚Äôs disease. My immune system destroyed my adrenal glands. Lots of fun. Needless to say, I am worried about coronavirus but I‚Äôve been prepping for weeks and since being diagnosed with this life-threatening disease 8 months ago I haven‚Äôt had so much as a sniffle. I stopped touching my face/started sanitizing my steering wheel/doors/phone as soon as I got home from being out. I have even lived with sick people and haven‚Äôt been sick whatsoever. Don‚Äôt resign yourself to living in fear. Be smart. The rest is out of our hands.
We don‚Äôt know that for sure yet. Too early to say.

Immunosuppression is based on dosage amount which is hard to calculate. 

I am on steroids, 30mg hydrocortisone a day but I am not immunosuppressed because I‚Äôm only taking a physiological replacement dose as my body doesn‚Äôt produce it naturally.
Hashimoto‚Äôs is one of the most common autoimmune disorders around and doesn‚Äôt affect your immune system. It shouldn‚Äôt have a bearing on anything.

I haven‚Äôt heard just the elderly being at risk but also those with underlying chronic medical conditions. I have an extremely rare autoimmune disease that makes even a stomach virus life-threatening. I‚Äôm worried too. Just stay inside as much as possible and disinfect everything you touch. Don‚Äôt touch your face. I have been doing those things for 8 months since my diagnosis and have not gotten so much as a sniffle, even living with sick people. Keep your chin up.
I‚Äôm in OK and haven‚Äôt heard/seen it anywhere.
Where did you see this?
Well, as long as we‚Äôre all predicting our own deaths...
It may not be unfounded but there is a difference between being concerned and cautious and being irrationally consumed with fear and being unable to cope.
Sounds like vasovagal syncope if you had only had blood drawn and nothing else going on. Did the syncope cause a full-blown, hospital-needing crisis for you?
Yikes. I‚Äôm glad I stocked up a couple of weeks ago. My paranoia finally came in handy. üòÇ

Well, obviously. I am also not a healthy individual. I didn‚Äôt say widespread testing was going to be unhelpful. They were speaking in first person about themselves being tested and that related to their own outcome. It‚Äôs a logic issue, not an overall statement on testing and the community.
If you actually read what I just wrote I am comparing seeking treatment when it isn‚Äôt medically necessary in both situations.
You not being tested has nothing to do with you becoming critically ill. Those are unrelated.
If she is having pain when breathing she shouldn't be looking for a test she should be looking for medical treatment at an ER. The test is not going to get her breathing better, an ER visit will.

Most people are not going to die from it. That's like getting help when you have the flu. Just because you have the flu doesn't mean you're going to become severely ill or develop a complication. If everyone that feels sick rushes to get medical assistance there's not going to be help available for people who are high-risk or actually NEED help.

I got an extra refill of my hydrocortisone, fludrocortisone and my emergency injections a couple of weeks ago. My insurance would not pay for an early refill but I paid for it (with a generous coupon) because this is very important. You want to minimize going to the pharmacy as much as possible but it is also possible to have medication shortages, so you want to get your refills now in case that happens.

Make sure she has an emergency kit with solu-cortef injections. I also keep Zofran in mine for vomiting, and anti-diarrheal medicines. I have electrolyte drink mix in there too.

She should have her own blood pressure monitor for home use, to monitor her BP in case she ever feels ill. And, of course, she absolutely must have a medical bracelet on at all times. It is wise to print out crisis symptoms/treatment information and put them on the fridge/in her purse/in her wallet.

These are things she should always have on hand, coronavirus or not. I was diagnosed in July and have not had a single cold/sniffle/etc. Nothing at all, even though I've been around and lived with sick people. I believe this is because once I was diagnosed, I realized getting sick was too dangerous for me. I always carry around a travel sized Lysol spray and hand sanitizer. I sanitize my steering wheel/car doors/keys/phone as soon as I return home from being in public. Then I wash my hands. I NEVER TOUCH MY FACE. That's the big one. She cannot touch her face anymore without washing her hands very, very well. This will prevent a lot of illness. Staying indoors is also important at this time as well as maintaining distance from people when she is in public.

I am worried about myself too but, at the end of the day, you can only do what you can to prevent illness. Stay away from people and stay as clean as possible. The rest is out of our hands.
Unfortunately, "preparing" for the general population apparently equates to panic buying excessive amounts of things.

If you are not a high-risk individual, worrying about it to the point of anxiety is probably not logical. If you are a high-risk individual, worry is understandable. The truth is, it's probably in every single state and has been for quite a while. We just haven't been testing.
That's not typically how mutations work. Use logic here.
If the choice is between hating the hospital and potentially dying, I'd take my chances. This is also why we inject and then get assistance. The injection is to buy time before getting help.

First of all, you need to get injections. Second of all, you need to have a blood pressure monitor at home to check yourself. This is one of the only ways we have of checking ourselves out at home. 

If you feel sick still, you need to go to the ER to get checked and get fluids/IV steroids.
I mean, that‚Äôs standard for what we know of Coronavirus so far. Asymptomatic spreading.
Please post actual, scientific backing for your ridiculous claims.
Your irrationality is disturbing.
I bet you have a lot of friends and are very popular at social gatherings.
Do you have a recipe?
Sounds like it‚Äôs from scratch then. I mean compared to buying the pre-flavored packets that are usually full of sugar and crap.
It's also flu season/cold season. I wouldn't automatically think coronavirus.
It's cute how you think medical professionals are known for their correct spelling and grammar. You must not know any.
I don't have the luxury of quitting my job. I need health insurance and money to, you know, live.

Dude. I have panic disorder and anxiety disorder. I also have an extremely rare disease called Addison‚Äôs disease that makes literally any illness a life or death situation. Am I worried? Of course. I actually have a good reason to worry. Does that mean I need to panic though? No. Because I‚Äôve done all I can and I‚Äôm prepared as much as one can be. There‚Äôs a difference between worrying and losing your mind for no reason. I know that if I‚Äôm worried I shouldn‚Äôt be looking at coronavirus related things. If you‚Äôre going to shut down any advice given to you then I don‚Äôt know why you made this thread. That level of worry is for a professional.

When you can‚Äôt control your circumstances your choices are to move on and do what you can to stay hygienic/out of the public or you can lose your mind and worry irrationally and ruin your life. You get to pick. Nobody can help you if you want to discount all logic and sound advice. 

It is possible to use the internet and avoid coronavirus news. I do it all the time. Don‚Äôt visit the news and don‚Äôt browse coronavirus subs.

It‚Äôs not everywhere. It‚Äôs on the internet and that‚Äôs avoidable. 

There‚Äôs nothing you can do about your parents either. You have even less control over other people.
I‚Äôm gonna need a recipe for that beautiful bread.

Therapy. Yesterday. 

There‚Äôs literally nothing you can do. You‚Äôre not in a high risk group and you don‚Äôt need to be irrational. I‚Äôm 28 and have a very rare disease that means any illness can kill me. I can‚Äôt go around losing my mind anytime a virus is making its rounds. Go about your life and stay off the internet/news if you can‚Äôt get therapy.

Get off the internet and stop looking at the news, for starters. That‚Äôs just feeding your anxiety loop.

There‚Äôs literally nothing you can do about this. And you‚Äôre not in a high-risk group. People that are dying are mostly all 50+/have health conditions. You are not the people who need to be afraid. Take control over your fear by staying as hygienic as possible and stay away from crowds/the general public. You‚Äôll be fine.
This isn't a problem if you're cooking your own food and not relying on processed stuff.

You're making this way too complicated. You don't need to overthink any of this. It's very simple. 

I'd stop worrying about fruit, first of all. It's called nature's candy for a reason. It should be treated as such. It is sugar with some fiber and vitamins/minerals but there is nothing in fruit that you can't get from vegetables in higher amounts without the sugar. That includes vitamin c and potassium. 

Grab your protein of choice. Cook it how you like it. Then get your veg of choice. Cook it how you like it. Add complex carbohydrate, if desired. It's very simple. This is what I do weekly and use it for lunches/dinners. Buy frozen veg so it doesn't go bad. Frozen veg is picked when truly ripe and doesn't sit around on a shelf going to hell so it's typically better for you. 

For instance: I roast chicken thighs/chicken breasts/whatever with garlic/herbs. Then I roast a sheet pan full of broccoli/carrots. Cook a pot of quinoa. Boom this is lunch/dinner for a few days. Sub in whatever meat/veg/carb.
If you're cooking it yourself from scratch and not adding sugar, yes.

Nooo! Ugh. Sorry you're sick! Hopefully it passes quickly. I cannot believe I've avoided getting a cold/anything so far. Everyone around me seems to be conspiring to get me sick. And of course coronavirus news is a joy to read about. I just got extra refills on my meds/emergency injections due to paranoia, lol.
I've never seen a cake like that! Very cool.
